page.title: Timeline of the United Kingdom home front during the First World War

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2018}} {{Main|History of the United Kingdom during the First World War}} [[File:Are you in this? LCCN2003652817.jpg|thumb|right|A 1917 poster designed by [[Robert Baden-Powell]] encouraging civilian participation in the war effort.]] This is a timeline of the British home front during the [[First World War]] from 1914 to 1918.
==1914== 28 June 1914 : [[Assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria]], heir to the [[Austro-Hungarian Empire|Austro-Hungarian throne]], who was killed in [[Sarajevo]] along with his wife [[Sophie, Duchess of Hohenberg|Duchess Sophie]] by Bosnian Serb [[Gavrilo Princip]]. [[File:Grand Fleet Assembly (front).jpg|thumb|right|An artist's impression of the [[Fleet Review]] on 18 July 1914.]] [[File:Britain declares war--Daily Mail Aug 5, 1914.jpg|thumb|''Daily Mail'' on Aug 5]] 27 July 1914 : [[Winston Churchill]] orders a "Test Mobilisation" for the [[Royal Navy]]'s [[Home Fleet]], which was at [[Portland Harbour]] following a [[Fleet Review]] by [[George V of the United Kingdom|King George V]]
28 July 1914 : [[Austro-Hungarian entry into World War I|Austria-Hungary]] declares war on Serbia.<ref name="LOC" /> [[Russia]] mobilizes.
29 July 1914 : The Home Fleet is ordered to its wartime anchorage at [[Scapa Flow]] in the [[Orkney Islands]].
1 August 1914 : [[German entry into World War I|Germany]] declares war on [[Russian entry into World War I|Russia]].<ref name="LOC">{{Cite web |url=https://www.loc.gov/law/help/digitized-books/world-war-i-declarations/foreign.php |title=Declarations of War from Around the World: Germany |date=31 July 1914 |website=Law Library of Congress |accessdate=9 May 2017}}</ref>
2 August 1914 : British cabinet decides on war.<ref>Keith M. Wilson, "The British Cabinet's decision for war, 2 August 1914." ''Review of International Studies'' 1.2 (1975): 148-159.</ref> : Germany invades [[Luxembourg]].
3 August 1914 : Germany declares war on [[French entry into World War I|France.]]<ref name="LOC" /> [[Belgium]] denies permission for German forces to pass through to the French border.
: Foreign Secretary Sir [[Edward Grey, 1st Viscount Grey of Fallodon|Edward Grey]] makes a speech to the [[British House of Commons|House of Commons]], asking Parliament to approve the use of armed force should the German Navy attack the coasts of France, or if Germany violates Belgian neutrality.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.1914-1918.net/greys_speech.htm |title=Sir Edward Grey's speech on the eve of war: 3 August 1914 |last1=Baker |first1=Chris |last2= |first2= |date= |website=www.1914-1918.net |publisher= |access-date=18 April 2015 }}</ref> [[File:The Outbreak of the First World War, 1914 Q81832.jpg|thumb|right|Crowds outside [[Buckingham Palace]] cheer King George, Queen Mary and the Prince of Wales (who can just be seen on the balcony) following the Declaration of War on 4 August 1914.]] 4 August 1914 : [[German invasion of Belgium|Germany invades Belgium]] to outflank the French army.
: British Government protests the violation of Belgian neutrality, guaranteed by the [[Treaty of London (1839)|Treaty of London]]; German Chancellor replies that the treaty is just a ''chiffon de papier'' (''a [[scrap of paper]]'').
: The United Kingdom declares war on Germany.<ref name ="Beckett216">Beckett (2006) p. 216</ref>
: British mobilisation: The Army and Navy Reserves are "called out" and the [[Territorial Force]] is "embodied" by Royal Proclamation.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.1914-1918.net/reserves_tf_mobilised.html |title=Proclamations that mobilised the army |last1=Baker |first1=Chris |last2= |first2= |date= |website=www.1914-1918.net |publisher= |access-date=18 April 2015 }}</ref>
5 August 1914 : The [[Aliens Registration Act 1914]] was introduced, compelling German immigrants in the United Kingdom to register with the police and making provision for the deportation or internment of those deemed to be a particular risk. [[File:Kitchener-leete.jpg|thumb|right|A poster supporting [[Herbert Kitchener, 1st Earl Kitchener|Lord Kitchener]]'s "call to arms", August 1914.]] : ''"Your King and Country need you: a call to arms"'' is published by [[Herbert Kitchener, 1st Earl Kitchener|Lord Kitchener]], the new [[Secretary of State for War]], calling for 100,000 men to enlist in the army. This figure is achieved within two weeks allowing six new [[division (military)|division]]s to be formed from these volunteers, to be called [[Kitchener's Army]]. From December 1914, battalions can be recruited from a specific locality, known as "[[Pals battalion]]s". By March 1915, a total of 41 new divisions have been raised.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.1914-1918.net/kitcheners.htm |title=Was my soldier in "Kitchener's Army"? |last=Baker |first=Chris |accessdate=15 August 2015}}</ref>
6 August 1914 : [[Currency and Bank Notes Act 1914]] authorises the issue of paper £1 and 10 [[Shilling (British coin)|shilling]] notes.<ref name ="Beckett216"/>
7 August 1914 : The [[British Expeditionary Force (World War I)|British Expeditionary Force]] arrives in [[France]].
8 August 1914 : The [[Defence of the Realm Act 1914]] (widely known as "DORA") is passed, imposing, censorship and security controls on the civil population.<ref>Doyle p.24</ref>
12 August 1914 : The United Kingdom declares war on Austria-Hungary.<ref name ="Beckett216"/>
September 1914 : German businesses in Britain are shutting down, for example the Münchener [[Löwenbräu]] London Depot. [[File:LondonLowenbrauLetter1914.jpg|thumb|right|A reference for an employee of a German-owned business in London, explaining its closing, September 1914.]]
November 1914 : First "dilution" agreement between the [[Engineering Employers Federation]] and [[trades union]]s, allowing unskilled workers (including women) to take on some of the roles usually reserved for skilled workers.<ref>Beckett (2006) p. 39</ref>
19 November 1914 : The Central Association of [[Volunteer Training Corps (World War I)|Volunteer Training Corps]] is recognised by the [[War Office]], legitimising the many town guards and local defence companies that have been formed illegally around the country.<ref>Beckett (1985) p. 15</ref>
3 December 1914 : The [[No Conscription Fellowship]] is formed.<ref>Beckett (2006) p. 153</ref>
16 December 1914 : A squadron of German [[battlecruiser]]s and other warships conduct a [[raid on Scarborough, Hartlepool and Whitby]], resulting in 137 deaths and 592 casualties, most of whom are civilians.<ref>Doyle p. 25</ref>
==1915== 9 January 1915 : [[Wilhelm II, German Emperor|Kaiser Wilhelm II]] authorises airship raids on the United Kingdom, excluding London.
19 January 1915 : The first air raid over Britain. Two German Navy [[Zeppelin]] airships drop bombs and incendiaries over [[Great Yarmouth]] and [[King's Lynn]] in [[Norfolk]]; four civilians are killed and sixteen injured.<ref>Doyle p. 26</ref> [[File:The German Zeppelin Raid on King's Lynn, January 1915 Q53587.jpg|thumb|right|Damage to houses in [[King's Lynn]] caused by a [[Zeppelin]] airship raid in 1915.]] 12 February 1915 : The Kaiser authorises airship raids on the [[London Docks]].
18 February 1915 : The Kaiser authorises an unrestricted [[Atlantic U-boat campaign of World War I|submarine blockade of the United Kingdom]].<ref name ="Beckett216"/>
16 March 1915 : Defence of the Realm (Amendment) (No 2) Act allows the government to force engineering firms to accept contracts for war related work.<ref>Beckett (2006) pp. 22–23</ref>
27 March 1915 : Commander-in-Chief of the BEF, Sir [[John Denton Pinkstone French, 1st Earl of Ypres|John French]] gave an interview to ''[[The Times]]'' highlighting the shortage of artillery ammunition at the front. This scandal was to become known the [[Shell Crisis of 1915|Shell Crisis]].
16 April 1915 : A single German [[Albatros B.II]] aircraft bombs [[Sittingbourne]] and [[Faversham]] in [[Kent]]; the first raid by an aeroplane. There are no casualties.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.iancastlezeppelin.co.uk/16th-april/4585768307 |title=Zeppelin Raids, Gothas and 'Giants' – 16th April 1915 – Kent |last1=Castle |first1=Ian |last2= |first2= |date= |website=www.iancastlezeppelin.co.uk |publisher= |access-date=19 April 2015}}</ref> [[File:Take Up the Sword of Justice.jpg|thumb|right|A poster published by the Parliamentary Recruiting Committee reflecting public anger at the sinking of [[RMS Lusitania|RMS ''Lusitania'']] on 7 May 1915. This was also the cause of rioting directed against German immigrants in several British cities.]] 7 May 1915 : The sinking of the British [[ocean liner]] [[RMS Lusitania|RMS ''Lusitania'']] by a [[U-boat]], with the loss of 1,198 passengers and crew, provokes anti-German riots in London and other cities. Mobs target shops and businesses owned by Germans or those with German surnames.
26 May 1915 : Prime Minister [[H. H. Asquith]] announces his [[Asquith coalition ministry|new ministry]], a [[coalition government]] with the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]]. [[David Lloyd George]] was made [[Minister of Munitions]], relieving Kitchener of that aspect of his role. Churchill is relieved of control of the [[Admiralty]] following the failure of the [[Gallipoli Campaign]].<ref name ="Beckett217">Beckett (2006) p. 217</ref>
31 May 1915 : First air raid on London; an Army Zeppelin dropped bombs over north and east London killing seven civilians.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.iancastlezeppelin.co.uk/31st-may/4586112684 |title=Zeppelin Raids, Gothas and 'Giants' – 31st May 1915 – London |last1=Castle |first1=Ian |last2= |first2= |date= |website=www.iancastlezeppelin.co.uk |publisher= |access-date=19 April 2015}}</ref>
July 1915 : Women's War Agricultural Committees established to encourage more women to work on the land.<ref name="Beckett 2006 p. 75">Beckett (2006) p. 75</ref>
2 July 1915 : The [[Munitions of War Act 1915]] becomes law, regulating the wages, hours and conditions of munitions workers. It becomes an offence for a worker to leave employment at a "Controlled Establishment" without the consent of the employer.
15 July 1915 : [[National Registration Act 1915]] was passed, requiring all men and women between the ages of 15 and 65 to register their address.<ref>Doyle p. 35</ref> [[File:Women at work during the First World War Q30617.jpg|thumb|right|A member of the Women's Hospital Corps in London, 1915.]] 17 July 1915 : [[Emmeline Pankhurst]] leads a "Women's Right to Serve" demonstration in [[Trafalgar Square]], London.<ref>Beckett (2006) p. 80</ref>
3 September 1915 : Lieutenant [[Leefe Robinson]] flying a [[Royal Aircraft Factory B.E.2|BE2]] biplane, shoots down the first German airship over British soil. The [[Schütte-Lanz SL 11]], which had been bombing north London and [[Saint Albans]], crashed in flames at [[Cuffley]] in [[Hertfordshire]].<ref name ="Beckett217"/>
16 October 1915 : Start enrolment for the [[Derby Scheme]] which encouraged men of military eligibility to voluntarily attest their willingness to join the armed forces at a later date. After attesting, men were placed on the Class B army reserve list until required. In return, they received a day's army pay and a khaki [[brassard]] which they could wear with their civilian clothes.
15 December 1915 : Finish of the [[Derby Scheme]] (originally planned for 30 November); although 2,950,514 men had attested, enlisted or tried to enlist during the scheme, a further 2,060,927 eligible men had refused to do so, increasing pressure for [[conscription]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://derbyscheme.wordpress.com/2013/01/19/derby-scheme/ |title=The Derby Scheme |accessdate=15 August 2015}}</ref>
==1916== [[File:Military Service Act 1916 poster IWM Art.IWM PST 5042.jpg|thumb|right|A government poster explaining how male workers can apply for exemption from conscription.]] 2 March 1916 : [[Military Service Act 1916]] comes into force, introducing compulsory conscription in Great Britain but not [[Ireland]]. Men from 18 to 41 years old were liable to be called up for service in the army unless they were married, widowed with children, serving in the Royal Navy, a minister of religion, or working in one of a number of reserved occupations. Local [[Military Service Tribunals]] could grant exemption from service, usually conditional or temporary.
2 April 1916 : An [[Faversham explosives industry#The Great Explosion|explosion at a munitions factory in Faversham]] kills 115 workers.
24–29 April 1916 : [[Easter Uprising]] by Irish Nationalists in [[Dublin]].<ref name ="Beckett217"/>
21 May 1916 : [[Daylight saving]] introduced in Britain, to save fuel for lighting and encourage longer working hours.<ref name ="Beckett217">Beckett (2006) p. 217</ref>
5 June 1916 : Lord Kitchener dies when the cruiser, [[HMS Hampshire (1903)|HMS ''Hampshire'']], which is carrying him to Russia, hits a [[naval mine|mine]] and sinks off the coast off the coast of Scotland. Lloyd George succeeds him as Secretary of State for War.<ref name ="Beckett217"/>
10 August 1916 : London [[première]] of ''[[The Battle of the Somme (film)|The Battle of the Somme]]'', giving audiences their first realistic impression of a modern battlefield. It is estimated that 20 million Britons had seen the film during the first six weeks of its release.<ref>Beckett (2006) p. 173</ref>
5 December 1916 : Lloyd George resigns as Minister of War, after Asquith fails to agree Lloyd George's plan for a new "War Council", prompting Asquith's resignation as Prime Minister the next day.<ref name ="Beckett217"/> [[File:David Lloyd George 1915.jpg|thumb|right|[[David Lloyd George]] became prime minister on 7 December 1916.]] 7 December 1916 : David Lloyd George forms a [[Lloyd George ministry|new coalition government]].
22 December 1916 : The first Ministry of Food was established under a food controller who, under the New Ministries and Secretaries Act 1916, was empowered to regulate the supply and consumption of food and take steps for encouraging food production. The Ministry was dissolved on 31 March 1921.
==1917== 19 January 1917 : An [[Silvertown explosion|explosion at a munitions factory in Slivertown]], [[West Ham]], kills 73 people.
2 February 1917 : [[Corn Production Act 1917]] guarantees minimum prices for staple food crops and lays down minimum wages for agricultural workers. It also initiates a "compulsory plough policy" which can force landowners to cultivate their land.<ref>Beckett (2006) pp. 112–113</ref> [[File:The Womens Land Army, 1917 Q114811.jpg|thumb|right|[[Women's Land Army]] farm workers in [[Hertfordshire]], 1917.]] March 1917 : A shortage of wheat leads to the introduction of "Government bread", which contains a proportion of flour made from [[oats]], [[barley]], [[rye]] or even potatoes.<ref>Beckett (2006) p. 116</ref> : [[Women's Land Army]] and [[Women's Forestry Corps]] are established.<ref name="Beckett 2006 p. 75"/>
28 March 1917 : [[Ministry of National Service]] is established.<ref name ="Beckett218">Beckett (2006) p. 218</ref>
21 May 1917 : The first [[National Kitchens|National Kitchen]] is opened by [[Mary of Teck|Queen Mary]] in [[Westminster Bridge Road]], London, providing cheap meals for those affected by food shortages.<ref>Beckett (2006) p. 124</ref> [[File:Gotha_RG_im_Flug.jpg|thumb|right|A German [[Gotha G.IV]] bomber in flight, 1917.]] 25 May 1917 : First raid on England by German [[Gotha G.IV|Gotha]] [[heavy bomber]] aircraft at [[Folkestone]] in Kent.<ref name ="Beckett218"/>
29 May 1917 : A [[royal proclamation]] issued by King George V encourages a voluntary reduction in bread consumption.<ref name ="Beckett218"/>
13 June 1917 : First attack on London by German heavy bombers; 104 civilians were killed, including 18 children at an [[Elementary school (England and Wales)|elementary school]] in [[Poplar, London|Poplar]].<ref name="Doyle p. 29">Doyle p. 29</ref>
July 1917 : The [[Metropolitan Police]] introduce their first [[air raid warning]] system, which consists of police officers detonating [[Maroon (rocket)|maroon]]s (a type of loud firework) and the "[[all clear]]" to be sounded by [[Boy Scout]] [[bugler]]s.<ref>Beckett (2006) p. 187</ref>
17 July 1917 : A royal proclamation issued by George V declares: "Our House and Family shall be styled and known as the [[House of Windsor|House and Family of Windsor]]", thus renouncing their German titles. [[File:A Good Riddance - George V of the United Kingdom cartoon in Punch, 1917.png|thumb|right|''"A Good Riddance"'': a cartoon in [[Punch magazine|''Punch'' magazine]] showing [[George V of the United Kingdom|King George V]] sweeping away his German titles in July 1917.]] 4 September 1917 : First night-time bomber raid on London.<ref>Castle & Hook p. 7</ref>
2 November 1917 : The Foreign Secretary, [[Arthur Balfour]], makes his [[Balfour Declaration|"Declaration"]] of the British intention to provide "a national home for the [[Jewish people]]" in [[Palestine (region)|Palestine]], which is being captured from the [[Ottoman Empire]].<ref name ="Beckett218"/>
17 December 1917 : Residents of [[Pontypool]] are issued with ration cards for sugar, tea, butter and margarine.<ref name ="Hibbert">{{cite web |url=http://www.hibbert-assembly.org.uk/food/rationing.htm |title=Food Rationing |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date= |website=www.hibbert-assembly.org.uk |publisher=Hibbert Trust |access-date=15 August 2015 |quote=}}</ref>
29 November 1917 : Former cabinet minister, [[Henry Petty-Fitzmaurice, 5th Marquess of Lansdowne]], writes a letter to the ''[[Daily Telegraph]]'' appealing for a peaceful settlement to the war which would become known as the "[[Lansdowne Letter]]".<ref name ="Beckett218"/>
31 December 1917 : National sugar rationing is introduced.<ref name ="Beckett218"/>
==1918== [[File:The Women's Royal Naval Service on the Home Front, 1917-1918 Q18898.jpg|thumb|right|A recruit to the [[Women's Royal Naval Service]] learning the parts of a rifle from a [[Royal Marine]] at the [[Crystal Palace Park|Crystal Palace]] depot.]] January 1918 : [[Women's Royal Naval Service]] is established.<ref>Beckett (2006) p. 73</ref>
1 January 1918 : Food rationing on certain items introduced in Birmingham, soon followed by other major towns and cities.<ref name ="Hibbert"/>
5 January 1918 : Lloyd George makes his War Aims speech to trades union leaders, setting out the government's terms for peace with the Central Powers.<ref name ="Beckett218"/>
16 February 1918 : First 1,000 kilogram (2,205 [[pound (weight)|pound]]) bomb is dropped on London during the twelfth night bomber raid.<ref name ="Castle&Hook8">Castle & Hook p. 8</ref>
25 February 1918 : Start of rationing of meat and fats in London and the [[Home Counties]].<ref name ="Beckett218"/>
1 April 1918 : [[Women's Royal Air Force]] is established.<ref name ="Beckett218"/>
18 April 1918 : [[Military Service (No. 2) Act 1918]] extends conscription up to age 50 and to residents of Ireland; although the latter is never implemented because of the [[Conscription Crisis of 1918|Conscription Crisis]].<ref name ="Beckett218"/> [[File:The people's war book; history, cyclopaedia and chronology of the great world war (1919) (14758829306).jpg|thumb|right|A mother and son view the remains of their home after an air raid in London.]] 19 May 1918 : The "[[Whitsun]] Raid" the largest and last of 17 bomber aeroplane raids on London;<ref name ="Castle&Hook8"/> 49 civilians are killed in London and Essex.<ref name="Doyle p. 29"/> The total number of civilian casualties from air raids since 1915 within London's [[Metropolitan Police District]] was 668 killed and 1,938 injured.<ref>White p. 252</ref>
10 June 1918 : [[Representation of the People Act 1918]] gives the vote to women over 30.
31 August 1918 : [[Metropolitan Police]] go on strike.
28 October 1918 : Peak mortality of the [[Spanish Flu]] pandemic in the UK.<ref name ="Beckett218"/>
11 November 1918 : Lloyd George announces that an [[Armistice of 11 November 1918|armistice]] has been signed and that hostilities will cease at 11 am. Church bells are rung and the [[Royal Family]] appear on the balcony of [[Buckingham Palace]] before cheering crowds.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/history/worldwars/wwone/mirror07_01.shtml |title=BBC History – Daily Mirror Headlines: Armistice, Published 12 November 1918 |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date= |website= |publisher=BBC |access-date=15 August 2015 |quote=}}</ref> [[File:Armistice Day in London, 11 November 1918 Q47852.jpg|thumb|right|Crowds outside Buckingham Palace on Armistice Day, 11 November 1918.]]

{{Infobox settlement | name = Zdynia | settlement_type = Village | total_type =   | image_skyline = Zdynia cerkiew.JPG | image_caption = Orthodox church | image_flag = | image_shield = | image_map = | subdivision_type = [[Countries of the world|Country]] | subdivision_name = {{POL}} | subdivision_type1 = [[Voivodeships of Poland|Voivodeship]] | subdivision_name1 = [[Lesser Poland Voivodeship|Lesser Poland]] | subdivision_type2 = [[Powiat|County]] | subdivision_name2 = [[Gorlice County|Gorlice]] | subdivision_type3 = [[Gmina]] | subdivision_name3 = [[Gmina Uście Gorlickie|Uście Gorlickie]] |pushpin_map=Poland |coordinates = {{coord|49|29|N|21|17|E|region:PL|display=inline}} | elevation_m = 500 - 550 | population_total = 220 | website = }} '''Zdynia''' {{IPAc-pl|'|z|d|y|ń|a}} ({{lang-rue|Ждыня}}, {{lang-uk|Ждиня}} ''Zhdynia'') is a [[village]] in the administrative district of [[Gmina Uście Gorlickie]], within [[Gorlice County]], [[Lesser Poland Voivodeship]], in southern [[Poland]], close to the border with [[Slovakia]].{{cite web |url=http://www.stat.gov.pl/broker/access/prefile/listPreFiles.jspa |title=Central Statistical Office (GUS) – TERYT (National Register of Territorial Land Apportionment Journal) |date=2008-06-01 |language=Polish}} It lies approximately {{convert|12|km|mi|0}} east of [[Uście Gorlickie]], {{convert|21|km|mi|0|abbr=on}} south-east of [[Gorlice]], and {{convert|117|km|mi|0|abbr=on}} south-east of the regional capital [[Kraków]]. The village has a population of 220. Zdynia is the site of an [[:pl:Łemkowska Watra w Żdyni|annual festival]] of [[Lemkos|Lemko]] culture. The village is located between mountains of [[Beskid Niski]] on the way of walking and cycle paths. It is also a place of one of the largest in [[Poland]] motorcycle gatherings.
